goal.en: This course introduces students to the emergent “beginnings” of literature across the world. The objectives of this survey are to develop a nuanced theoretical and historical understanding of the category of “literature,” the history of literature as it is pertinent to the study of English Literature (and beyond), to grasp fundamental theories and tools of linguistic anthropology and historical linguistic that can aid students in the study of literature in the past and in more recent times, to develop individual answers to the question, “what is the relationship between literature and society?” To learn about how origins are illusory and that historical threads are not always chronological is one of the key lessons the course will teach. Each week after the introductory session, students will engage with a different ancient culture. The lessons will be divided into an introductory lecture, a short break to review the week’s reading, and then group work and mini lectures/presentations on the sample texts for the week. In some cases, we will read longer works over two weeks. Students must complete a short response essay (300 words) after we complete each subunit. There will be a midterm based on identifying and defining key terms that we will learn each week. The final assignment will be a paper, the topic of which will be determined through conversations with the instructor.

content.en:
Week 1 – Introduction
In this introductory session students will listen to a lecture on the basic history of early human expression, the emergence of writing, and the basics of historical linguistics as it applies to this course. Some examples from later in the course will be introduced to provide this outline, emphasizing various issues related to periodization. At the end of the session there will be plenty of time to ask questions and to make sure we are all on the same page moving forward.
Key Terms: language family, script vs. language, contact/borrowing, proto- vs. pre-language, isolate language, language tree, oral vs. written, periodization, the “comparative method,” center/periphery, discovery ＆ decipherment, genealogy/typology, etymology.
Week 2 – Mesopotamia 1 (Sumerian, Akkadian)
Introductory lecture on the cuneiform languages (Sumerian, Akkadian, Hittites), and on the so-called “epic” of Gilgamesh.
Reading: Epic of Gilgamesh (trans. Helle) Tablets 1-5
Key Terms: Mesopotamia, cuneiform script, Mesopotamian (languages), tablets, Sumerian/Neosumerian, Old Babylonian, Middle Babylonian, Standard Literary Version, textual self-authentication, Gilgamesh, Enkidu, Shamhat.
Week 3 – Mesopotamia 2 (Akkadian, Hittite)
Discussion of Res of Epic of Gilgamesh. Lecture on Anatolian Languages, early literature (Wilusa, Mitanni Treaty), Hittite mythology and relation to Hurrian language and myth. Discussion of Hittite text and small appendices to readings.
Reading: Epic of Gilgamesh Tablets 6-11 (12 optional); Song of Ullikummi; “Song of Wilusa”
Key Terms: Ut-Napishti/Ziusudra, Anatolian, Hieroglyphic vs Cuneiform Luwian (+ confusion with Hittite), Historical Troy, Ancient Mediterranean World
Week 4 – Levant (Ugaritic, Biblical Hebrew)
Introduction to history of the Bible’s composition. Discussion of selections from The Book of Genesis and some comparanda from Mesopotamia.
Readings: Ugaritic Ba’al Cycle (selections); Hebrew Genesis (selections)
Key Terms: origin myth, reduplication/doubling, labor, etiology
Week 5 – Ancient Greece 1 (Homeric Greek)
Introductory lecture on Ancient Greek language and poetic culture. Discussion of readings from Homeric poems.
Readings: Selections from Odyssey and Iliad
Key Terms: Formula, Oral Composition, The Greek Hero
Week 6 – Ancient Greece 2 (Hesiodic and Archaic Literature)
Lecture on Hesiodic corpus and Pindaric Odes; discussion of texts.
Readings: Hesiod’s Theogony and Pindar Olympian 1
Key Words: Theogony, Block-Composition, Epinician
Week 7 – Ancient Rome (Latin)
Lecture on Early Latin literature, outline of different phases of Roman literature. Emphasis on Virgil – group activity reading extract from Virgil.
Readings: Old Latin Comedy extract; Virgil Aeneid (extract)
Key Words: doubled origin, reception, intertextuality
Week 8 – Ancient Iceland and Norway (Old Norse)
Lecture on Snorri and the structure of Old Norse literary corpus. Discussion of readings from the Eddas and from Heimskringla. Student activity reading a famous scene from Njal’s Saga.
Readings: prologue to Prose Edda, one text from Poetic Edda, passage from Ynglinga Saga of the Heimskringla, passage from Njal’s Saga
Key Terms: prosimetrum, saga, skaldic, eddas
Week 9 – Ancient Ireland (Old and Middle Irish)
Lecture on Old Irish Cycles, Middle Irish literature that responds to Greco-Roman antiquity.
Readings: Extracts from Táin Bó Cúailnge; Ulixes son of Laertes
Key Terms: cycle, reception, Irish rhyme
Week 10 – Ancient Iran (Avestan)
Lecture on the Avesta and its structure.
Readings: Gathas, Hymn to Mithra, Vendidad II
Key Terms: liturgy, intercalation
Week 11 – Ancient India 1 (Vedic Sanskrit)
Lecture on the Vedas and adjacent texts.
Readings: Selected Hymns from the Rigveda
Key Terms: speculative hymn, dramatic hymn, do ut des, rta
Week 12 – Ancient India 2 (Epic Sanskrit)
Lecture on Mahabharata
Readings: Extracts from the Mahabharata
Key Terms: dharma, heroism and pessimism
Week 13 – Ancient India 3 (Prakrit, etc.)
Lecture on Prakrit and other MIA languages and their relation to Sanskrit.
Readings: Extracts from Prakrit Setubandha and Sattasai (with Sanskrit comparison)
Key Terms: language order, diegetic frames, extradiegetic frames
Week 14 – Ancient Pakistan/China (Gandhari, Tocharian)
Introduction to Gandhara and Tarim Basin.
Readings: Gandhari poetry, Tocharian B love poem, Tocharian A story of the Maiden
Key Terms: ajiva verses, paleographic analysis
Week 15 – Early England (Old ＆ Middle English)
Introduction to early English poetry. Activity deciphering Middle English (Skelton, Chaucer, Gawain poet)
Readings: Wanderer, Seafarer, extracts from Beowulf
Key Terms: stressed meters, alliterative verse
Week 16 – Ancient China (group presentations)
Student-led exploration of the emergence of literature in Chinese.

Before the muses: An anthology of Akkadian literature. cdl Press, 2005. Helle, Sophus, ed. Gilgamesh: A New Translation of the Ancient Epic. Yale University Press, 2021. Jacobsen, Thorkild. The Harps that once--: Sumerian poetry in translation. Yale University Press, 1987. Smith, John D. The mahabharata. Penguin, 2009. Wilson, Emily. “The Odyssey: Homer.“ New York/London (2018).
